TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit SearchAndProcessItem extends Microsoft.Office.RecordsManagement.SearchAndProcess.SearchParameters

Docs.summary: Represents the search and process operation that you want to execute, and includes a method to initiate the operation.

remarks.para: Search and process operations enable you to use Microsoft SharePoint Server 2010 to perform a search query, and then perform a specific, custom action upon each list item returned by the query. For example, you might need to identify a certain set of documents, based on specific document metadata, and then move those documents into a records repository.
The assembly you specify must implement the interface.
Use the method to add the search and process operation to the SharePoint Server 2010 master timer job.

Docs.param: The keyword query for the search operation.
The search application to use for the search operation.
The name of the assembly to call to process each item returned by the search.
The name of the class within the assembly to call to process each item returned by the search.

Public Function Add (web As SPWeb, schedule As DateTime, gParentId As Guid, nItemId As Integer, fRememberWebId As Boolean, gItemUniqueId As Guid, gBatchId As Guid, nUserId As Integer) As Guid
public: Guid Add(Microsoft::SharePoint::SPWeb ^ web, DateTime schedule, Guid gParentId, int nItemId, bool fRememberWebId, Guid gItemUniqueId, Guid gBatchId, int nUserId);

Docs.param: The site on which the search and process operation is to be run.
The date and time when you want the search and process operation to run.
A GUID that identifies the parent of the work item.
A 32-bit integer that identifies a list item associated with the work item.
true to set the web identifier; otherwise, false.

A GUID that specifies a context identifier to the job work item engine. The value can vary depending on the job type; for example, for alerts it may store a user ID but for workflow it would store a workflow ID.
The user on whose behalf the search and process operation is being performed.
Docs.summary: Adds the search and process job to the Microsoft Office SharePoint Server 2007 master timer job.
Docs.returns: A GUID that represents the GUID of the timer job created for this request.

remarks.para: The Add method throws an exception if any of the following occurs:

item.description: The referenced assembly cannot be found, or does not implement the interface.
The time you have specified for the job to run is invalid. For example, you have specified a time in the past.

remarks.para: The search and process operation is created as a one-time, asynchronous timer job.

The parameter enables you to specify the user on whose behalf the search and process operation is being performed. Items to which the user does not have sufficient rights are not included in the return set of the search and process operations.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::String ^ AssemblyName { System::String ^ get(); void set(System::String ^ value); };

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the name of the assembly that contains the class which implements the IProcess interface.
Docs.value: A string that represents the fully qualified name of the assembly.

remarks.para: Use the property to return the name of the assembly to call to process each item returned by the search.
This class is used to process each item returned by the search.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::String ^ ClassName { System::String ^ get(); void set(System::String ^ value); };

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the name of the class that implements the IProcess interface. This class is used to process each item returned by the search.
Docs.value: A string that represents the name of the class in the assembly.

remarks.para: The specified class must exist in the specified assembly name.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets any optional arguments to pass to the process assembly and class.
Docs.value: A string array that represents the optional arguments to pass to the process assembly and class.

remarks.para: The method arguments passed to the process assembly can be any values that the process assembly can parse; SharePoint Server 2010 does not process these arguments.
Use the property to return the name of the assembly to call to process each item returned by the search.
Use the property to return the name of the assembly to call to process each item returned by the search.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the number of search results requested for this query.
Docs.value: A short value that indicates the number of search results requested for this query.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::String ^ SearchApplication { System::String ^ get(); void set(System::String ^ value); };

Docs.summary: Specifies the search application to use for the search operation.
Docs.value: A string that represents the name of the search application to use for the search operation.

remarks.para: The search application specified must be a registered Search provider for the specified site.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public static hidebysig void UnregisterSearchEngine(class Microsoft.SharePoint.Administration.SPWebApplication webApplication) cil managed
Public Shared Sub UnregisterSearchEngine (webApplication As SPWebApplication)
public: property System::String ^ UsersToNotify { System::String ^ get(); void set(System::String ^ value); };

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a list of the e-mail addresses of the users to send a report to by e-mail on the search and process job results.
Docs.value: A string that represents a semicolon-delimited list of the e-mail addresses.

remarks.para: After the search and process operation has called the specified assembly class on all the items in the search return set, SharePoint Server 2010 generates a report of the results, with detailed processing results for each list item in the return set. It then sends an e-mail message with the report to the specified users.
